Gillette is a capitalistic, profit-oriented company that, like all other companies, wants to maximize that profit. This is not a convent with nuns that pray for world peace for crying out loud. Is the supermarket area where the Gillette razors are stored our new pulpit? Should I confess my sins when I go to the bathroom in the morning?  Can I throw my used razors in the garbage bin or has it become a holy relic of the church of Gillette? The whole situation is ridiculous.

‚Äã@Dennis, the commercial did not mention or display anything that would lead you to believe that "men are the root of evil", as you said. That is, of course, unless you bring that assumption with you. It is clear to me that was the commercial displays is a call for men to live up to higher and better standards. Bullying is wrong regardless of who is perpetrating or receiving, but men have long been cultured towards violence and sexual objectification. It baffles me that anyone could disagree with the simple mantra "men need to hold other men accountable". It really is noncontroversial. It isn't an attack on men, but on toxic masculinity. 

I won't mention any one specific study just to make a point, but it has been well demonstrated in behavioral science studies that young girls who observer are victims of domestic violence at a young age are more likely to end up in abusive relationships and become victims of further domestic violence as adults. While young boys who observe domestic silence at a young age are more likely to commit domestic violence. This is one small sad example of what I hope you learn to see: that "men need to hold other men accountable".

Because it promotes the idea that males are the root of all evil.  When your wife can hit you in the face with a brick and then call the cops and get you arrested because "he must have deserved it" maybe then you'll understand.

Why does that ad pretending "bullying" is a male thing?  A recent study showed 2/3rds of women feel bullied by their female coworkers. At least men stop bullying once we enter adulthood.

@Tanner Whetzel Of course the main audience of this particular ad are men‚Ä¶‚Ä¶but Gillette and P&G produce plenty of products aimed at women (one could argue the majority of them).  So why haven‚Äôt they produced a similar ad aimed at women based on one of the products aimed at women (e.g. Venus shavers).

@EL JAY, 

"Why do you take the backlash against this ad to be evidence that people are against male accountability?"

I am not necessarily conflating them, but why do you suggest people disliked the ad so adamantly? Deflecting and saying, well what about women, what about there only being white men, these are ultimately sidestepping the point "men need to hold other men accountable".

"Surely addressing toxic behaviour in both genders would have an even greater positive effect on society - no?"

I hope this is not too far a stretch, but I am assuming that the main audience of this ad is the same as the consumer target of Gillette products (men). Why is Gillette in any way responsible for calling women to better action in combatting toxic behavior? It was well targeted to address men for that and because we live in a world that has long been dominated by men. We still live in a world full of 'dominating men'. Toxic masculinity makes me sick because I am a man and I will not make excuses for the boyish behavior so many men exhibit today. 

What do you think about the afformentioned ethic quoted by Terry Crews: "men need to hold other men accountable".

@EL JAY. I think it is reading way into it to interpret the meaning of this as a challenge only for white men. It is a challenge for men to be better men in general. Regardless of any toxicity mitigated by women, the point is, men need to hold other men accountable. I love that so much and it is what our goofy culture needs. When I first saw this ad, I honestly thought it wasn‚Äôt a commercial and was a sermon series from a megachurch on Godly men. I had no idea people were against the idea of male accountability. We need it so desperately.

Ok - for the sake of argument you are correct, this isn't just an attack on men and its a genuine attempt to help (some) men be better.  Where is the similar advert aimed at women?  

Women and girls exhibit a lot of toxic behaviour too such as bullying, (psychological and physical), gossip, paternity fraud, baby trapping, maliciously withholding access to children, domestic abuse etc.  Should women not be holding other women accountable in a similar manner?

Why is it only men (and white men in particular judging by the ad) who need their behaviours put in check?

Y'all completely missed the point of Gillette's ad. It's not for misogynistic, rapist men. It's for millenial, and gen z men that are more likely to be progressive and want to make a change. It's not attacking masculinity, it's attacking toxic masculinity. Many boys and men know they're not horrible people but do not know how to be better. Men want to be better but how can they be when they are constantly being shown and advertised to objectify women, that their opinion matters more than a woman's, that they're not supposed to have any vulnerabilities, that confiding in people makes them weak, etc. Gillette's ad was showing that men deserve better than toxic masculinity, and that there is hope for the future generation of men to break out of this toxic mold that has been fed to them constantly which is harming both boys, girls, men, women, everybody. Also, that ad wasn't showing all men being pieces of shits, it shows stereotypical situations that men have been taught to deal with, and changes it to reveal that men are good people and have been fed the lie of toxic masculinity. There is nothing wrong with masculinity, toxic masculinity is not true masculinity. Men are not shitty, men are not trash, and men deserve hope. That is what Gillette was showing.

I'm not sure why Gillette thought that they're brand was the right way to spread awareness of the controversy, but the ad did what it's purpose was, and that was to spread awareness of the toxic masculinity controversy. Pick your battles and live your life as an example of how you would like others to live.

Stick around people that will lift you up, walk away from those that put you down.

Too many people react to this commercial like it's man hating but that's not the problem. The problem is it is both preachy and poorly delivered. The inner message is just don't be a dick, but the vast majority of people don't need to be told that. So being told we need to teach our fellow men to "think and act the right way," (poor phrasing, again, terrible execution in an already unnecessary commercial) is just naturally gonna come across the wrong way to many people. 

Now many have taken it personal and been galvanized and offended by some commerical into feeling even further confirmation bias that  any mention to "toxic masculinity" equates to an attack on men. The fact is both masculinity and feminity can be toxic. Assaulting someone to assert your dominance is toxic in a modern society, and so is a mother being overly protective and coddling their children to the point they have no chance to strengthen and grow, and nowhere near enough people hit on that last one, and that's where I take issue. Where is some anti toxic feminity activism?

Both genders have certain traits they are bias towards that like anything when taken to an extreme becomes a problem. The real problem here is something else entirely that Gillette didn't touch on. Like I said everyone worth a shit knows about consent and all we don't need to be told about that. But what about the increasingly common helicopter parents, that coddle their young boys and refuse to let them do anything that might bruise their wittle arm? What about the times when men are assertive and even violent when they need to be, yet they are ridiculed for it? What about all the schools now with zero tolerance policy's for fighting, where you will be punished for the crime of defending yourself against a bully violently assaulting you? These are clear and present examples of "toxic" feminity (or at least "toxic" pacifism) run amok to a very dangerous extreme, yet it rarely gets talked about.

Can't agree with Rogan on this. First of all, the product is irrelevant. The point of advertising is to send a message that invokes a feeling, then associate the product/brand with that feeling in hopes that people will buy the product/be more loyal to the brand. If you look at this commercial honestly, it's no different of every other commercial that encourages people to be good to one another. Car insurance, Pepsi, Coke, you name it. They all try to do the same thing, no matter what product/brand is being sold/marketed. 

Second, Joe's flat out wrong about the commercial making all men look like shit. The commercial isn't saying that all men, or even most men, are pieces of shit. It's suggesting that *too many* men either don't do the right thing, or simply allow stupid shit to happen way too often. They LITERALLY show men doing the right thing at the end of the commercial to prove that we're not all shitty people and that we *can* be good to one another.  

Catcalling is a problem, bullying is a problem, and sexual harassment is a problem. Anyone with a sister/wife/girlfriend/ and especially daughter should know this. Masculinity is not inherently a bad thing. But something's wrong with us if we don't let ourselves see the fucked up shit it can enable when left unchecked. Sure, everyone has their own issues. Women have issues, kids have issues, and men have issues. Procter and Gamble happens to focus on the latter because they're a family company and they fucking can.

I honestly don't know what y'all's problem with the ad is.

I guess my issue is that, in the Me Too movement, a lot of it is harassment. I don't like to take "harassment" as is - it's very vaguely defined, and so I like to read the articles if I want to speak on. For some of them, I don't find the issue as severe as the headline would make me think, but for others... yeah, it's bad.
The one that is currently in the forefront of my mind is this article about Disney Pixar, and a lot of what I have to say comes from it.
https://variety.com/2018/film/news/pixar-boys-club-john-lasseter-cassandra-smolcic-1202858982/

One situation that particularly disturbed me were examples of women telling newcomers to not go into a room alone with particular men. Or the situations where, to avoid "distracting" executives, they would avoid inviting female workers to meetings where sexist executives would be.

In these areas of sustained harassment, I really wonder; What are the men doing?
I would assume some men would be like the women, telling women who to keep away from. There were men who would just cringe and look away. Some would diffuse situations like the ones who dis-invited women from meetings with sexist executives. I assume some would enjoy the powers and privileges that resulted from encumbered and harassed women.

Rogan makes the point to Gillette that "you don't have your shit together. Nobody has their shit together." I think this ad isn't directed at areas where we don't know what to do. It's directed at places where, in a calm setting, we all know what shit we'd want to do. The issue is that many men don't do it.

The main contentions are that 1,
That harassment is real. I think Joe Rogan understands that. I think a lot of people understand that. Even if you read the article above, and you're like "this is just one story," there are others. There are many others. Eventually the reality of the situation will settle into you.

And then 2,
Most men who watch women being clearly spoken over, or being awkwardly touched when they clearly don't like it, do almost nothing at all.
There ARE men who just cringe and look away when they see harassment, and the idea that this ad can't give them a helpful example for how to handle such a situation or the self-assurance that they are engaging in proper behavior... I don't comprehend your certainty that this ad can do nothing in that respect.

I've had one nice comment to my prior post on this subject and a lot of nasty ones and the one nice comment asked why I was so opposed to this Gillette commercial. I had time to think and also to discuss it with like-minded friends and we came to the following conclusions: 

1. Gillette is a subdivision of Proctor and Gamble. At last check, Gillette is not normally in the business of moral authority or even counseling in the normal sense. 

2. Gillette is part of a corporation. It's SOLE motivation to it's shareholders is to earn lots and lots of $$$. So any commercial it makes, at great expense mind you, is SPECIFICALLY targeted at an audience it wants to part $$$ from in exchange for it's overpriced razors. 

3. Gillette's share of the market is tanking due to it's high prices and not keeping up with lower-priced competition that is running circles around it. This creates a sense of desperation on the part of Gillette to find a means to survive and thrive. It seems to be targeting a new market. Whether that market is men or women is up for debate, but rest assured, this isn't being done out of the goodness of Gillette's greedy little heart. 

4. Like so many tech giants are so blatantly showing themselves to be , much of corporate America now is taking a left-leaning slant in their operations in order to comply with a larger initiative that we know exists and is geared towards an increasingly socialist and one-world viewpoint that is, by necessity, hostile to U.S. and other nationalist countries. The Internet has, as a by-product of it's crossing international borders, created this sense of "one-worldism" that so falls specifically into the very willing hands of those who would implement a disastrous one-world government. 

5. It is ABSOLUTELY clear that these larger interests have a vested mission to bring men down in both stature and in social standing in order to make men doubt themselves and to adopt a more feminine / pacifist role than traditionally men of older ages would have put up with. It is VERY threatening to these powers-that-be to have men with their traditional viewpoints in the world and they are doing everything in their power to produce new generations of literal snowflakes (who can be easily controlled and swayed) rather than men 

6. We MEN who have minds that penetrate, eyes to see and whose thoughts looks beyond the obvious can discern the motivations and machinations of those whose surface intentions seem legitimate but in reality are anything but. 

So, our bottom line is this: We instinctively recoiled at seeing a corporate entity assume this posture that would normally be the territory of theologians and philosophers as well as family counselors and the like. And having seen corporate American boardrooms up close and personal, we know that this isn't what it seems to be. We prefer to remain MEN and not be pulled to and fro by the puppeteers who have fooled many over the history of mankind. I am personally reminded of Stalin, Hitler, Ghengis Khan and so many others who claimed to be one thing in the beginning and who turned out to be quite another once the reign of power fell into their hands. 

I will NOT reply to a single one of you so don't waste your time trying to get me to speak since it is pointless to argue with an opposing view that often cites facts that haven't been vetted, which haven't been researched properly and which haven't even passed the exacting science of critical thought. I have more valuable things to do with my time than try to convince others of my point of view and I bid you all a pleasant day or night as the case may be.

I like Joe Rogan. But, I also like the Gillette ad. Sure, most people know they are not supposed to be racist, or sexist... but a lot of people ARE nonethless, as we have seen with the rise of white nationalism lately - people coming out in the open after Trump implied it was ok to do so. But, even more important than THAT aspect of the commercial was the idea of TOXIC MASCULINITY. I didn't take the ad as saying we should feel shame for being men, but rather as a call to be inspired to be better, and to encourage our friends to be better. As well, it raises the issue of toxic masculinity, which in my mind is a very harmful thing. 

 I truly believe men are harmed by all the bullshit standards we are programmed with. We are not allowed to cry, not allowed to show emotion, not allowed to hug our best friend (unless we aggressively slap their back, and the hug is short without any true feeling behind it). We are not allowed to talk about our feelings, and we are therefore prevented - unlike women - from actually healing ourselves after grief/loss. We are encouraged to have sex as soon as possible, and to be aggressive with each other (rather than negotiating through conflict). Everything about our society teaches men that we must be cold, dispassionate, unfeeling, non-communicative, muscular beasts instead of thoughtful, compassionate, feeling human beings. YES! We are different from women. No! We don't have to become soft. However, in my mind the most courageous men are those who have the courage to show their emotion to other men (knowing it could lead to ostracism) - to take such a big chance that their friend will accept it, and maybe even show some emotion back. Men USED TO be like that. If you look at photos of men working in mining town etc 100+ years ago or more, men would lay on the laps of their colleagues for the photo, and would embrace each other with love. Nowadays, any attempt to actually show human connection would face ostracism due to the FEAR of being labelled gay or a sissy. Men need to recognize that such sentiments are based out of FEAR, not masculinity. The truly masculine man has the COURAGE to show their true heart. If other men aren't ready for it, or default to programmed judgment, then they are cowards.

@Microtransaction Harassing is any behaviour which violates personal boundaries of individual and seeks to subordinate and coerce them into doing activities against their will. Those rom coms are prominent examples of how harassment is taught to be normalized in our culture. While what constitutes boundary violation to a person can vary according to individual, the notion of harassment as an action which violates personal boundaries regardless of what those said boundaries are defined by is not a matter of opinion. If someone is having their physical space violated according to their predefined standards, that is harassment. For the majority of women, catcalling is a form of harassment because its an objectifying behaviour that exists on a continuum of behaviours include stalking, groping and ultimately rape. Any action that seeks to dehumanize another person is not entirely a matter of opinion.

If there wasn't a valid issue that needed addressing, the outrage being displayed in this comment section simply would not exist. What in the fuck are you guys upset about? This is just an ad from a huge corporation which addresses some age old problems in the way some men view and treat women. 

If you didn't perceive yourself as being one of the people this ad targets, then you wouldn't even give it a second thought. You'd probably even go as far as to view it in a positive light, and feel it might be what some guys need to decide to make a positive change within themselves... Why is that bad in any way?

I'm actually quite disheartened by the level of outrage and negativity in this comment section... Somehow, of the two-hundred or so comments I scanned, I saw nothing else. Every last comment was negative... with most voicing their opposition quite emphatically. I had no idea this culture was still so prevalent. I honestly thought most men had rounded the corner of misogyny and abuse, but it appears that I was a bit out of the proverbial loop on this topic.

Bottom line. If you're outraged over something as innocuous as this ad, then you take issue with the message it delivers. Why would you ever take issue with the respectful treatment of women? I knew this issue was far from being eradicated from society, but to see so many men and even women becoming so outraged over something which, in my opinion, delivers a message which is exceedingly positive and provides hope for a better tomorrow, is definitely an eye opener.

I'd like to close by informing everyone who is outraged over this ad of just one thing... YOU are a part of a much bigger problem. A problem which has caused more needless emotional and physical pain than any war ever has. Please take some time to evaluate the anger you are currently experiencing. There is absolutely no valid or rational reason for you to be upset over this ad. The fact you are should be more than just a little concerning... Not only to others, but to yourselves as well. 

The culture you're all defending so vehemently is the mistreatment of women. Don't try and disguise it as being something else, because that is precisely what it is. Fuck off with that weak, insecure bullshit... Stand up for masculinity by actually acting like a man... Not like some spoiled child, experiencing the various inconveniences which inevitably come with our first taste of responsibility. We all should eagerly accept the responsibility that is showing everyone the same level of respect we expect to receive ourselves. Those who have chosen to shirk or ignore this seemingly simple gesture are directly responsible for a truly unbelievable amount of human suffering and injustice.  

Real men don't mistreat women, or anyone else for that matter. Self-improvement can only be achieved through one's invested efforts into themselves, and never through the senseless tearing down of others. While diminishing others might cause you to feel somehow better at that moment, such feelings are nothing more than an temporary illusion. You haven't actually improved, or achieved anything. You've simply become yet another cog in an extremely problematic machine.

Men began growing out their beards and quit shaving about seven years ago.  With the exception of the food service industry very few jobs require a clean shave in this generation.  Men's shaving companies have been losing money for a decade due to this trend.  

It was no accident this commercial was produced in a manner many men may find offensive. This no doubt was a marketing strategy aimed at reeling in more females to buy their products.  Rather than directing a campaign for the female product line they created a commercial heavy on the social justice virtue signaling appearing to be directed at males.  This was no doubt done knowing there would be throwback from male customers, triggering the #metoo movement to make the case for toxic men offended by a commercial promoting goodness.  

The owners knew this campaign would pick up more views and more steam trending on social media than it possibly could as a ladies razor commercial airing daily on television.   Sound about right?  

Females in numbers are still shaving their legs, under their arms as well as more personal places.  This marketing strategy is aimed at them. The rational? No big deal if you lose offended male customers because they're not shaving anymore anyways.

At least that is my take on the matter.

I think I figured out why I hate this commercial despite the fact that I‚Äôm not an MRA, a creep, a misogynist, or a bully.  I was watching Seinfeld and Jerry has an argument with his gf.  He‚Äôs looking for something and she says  to check the drawer.  Jerry: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not stupid, I‚Äôm looking right at the drawer.‚Äù  Her: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt say you were stupid!‚Äù  Jerry: ‚ÄúWell wouldn‚Äôt I have to be?‚Äù

This is the conceit of the commercial.  It‚Äôs calling me a sexist pig, and then when I object because I‚Äôm not a sexist pig, the response from our culture is saying I‚Äôm the problem because I *must* be a sexist pig, while Gillette is saying they never called me a sexist pig.  But wouldn‚Äôt I have to be if you assumed that I was and you felt you had to lecture me?  I‚Äôm damned either way, so yes I feel insulted and stereotyped by this commercial.  That‚Äôs the position this preachy commercial puts all men in, so I think the anger at it is justifiable.

You can‚Äôt show terrible examples of bad people doing asshole things in order to ask ‚Äòis this the best men can get?‚Äô without the assumptions that these behaviors are part of being a man, that men are currently no better than this, and that they *need* improvement or are not good enough as-is.  That assumption is deeply tied into this idea that the primary problem with rapists, abusers, harassers, etc is not that they‚Äôre assholes doing illegal shit but that they‚Äôre men.  I absolutely believe that it is sexist and wrong to assume that this ‚Äòtoxic masculinity‚Äô is part of being a man rather than a symptom of being a bad person.

I've had guys say absurd things like, "you should be careful out here while you're wearing something like that" -- when I was wearing a KNEE length skirt and a long sleeved shirt. Re: "More Community Oriented"

This needs to be expanded upon because we've changed the meaning of the word "community" online. There¬†is a YouTube "Community" here, which I can be a part of wherever I go in the world. I'm in Canada now, but if I were to go to Chad, I could still be part of the "community". If I were to go to Antarctica, I would still be part of that "community".

But to many rural people (in particular; this seems to be a fairly clear Rural/Urban divide, though not exclusively Rural) community is the LAND. The buildings. Sitting down on a porch with a neighbour after work. Going to Church gatherings (even if it's more for the social aspect than the religious aspect - another thing many Urban folk don't get). That's community to them.¬†And if they physically leave that area? They aren't a part of¬†that community¬†anymore. They don't consider an Online Community to be the same as a real life community. A "Rural Town in Texas" Facebook group isn't the same as being in that rural town in Texas.

This is something many Urban people simply don't get. Probably because we've conditioned ourselves over the past 60 years to "go to where the jobs are". If you're in Dallas, and a better job opens up in Mobile, you go to Mobile. If a better job opens up in St. Louis, you go to St. Louis. Or New York. Or Los Angeles. Or wherever the job is. And we think about the friends we've made along the way as our "Community", and we're content with a facebook post or a text or a phone call once in a while, and maybe we'll go there for a weekend one day when we've got a bit of time, just to have drinks with old friends then go back "home".

Rural and Urban folk are using the same words to refer to different things these days - we're divided by a shared language.

"Toxic masculinity" is an adverb in front of an adjective. "Toxic" describes a kind of masculinity, it is not a description of all masculinity. This is the same as saying poisonous berries. Getting rid of toxic masculinity benefits men just as much as it does women. The vast majority of violence is committed by men - men who are a product of toxic masculine culture. Every man including myself has been affected by toxic masculinity to some degree. The whole "bad apples" argument is flawed because it assumes that violence is an entirely individualized phenomena and the neglects the role socialization and acculturation plays in shaping in violence perpetrated by men. Also, before you falsely tout the ad as "anti-masculine", know that masculine roles have varied enormously throughout human history. The ad concerns two very specific aspects of masculinity: harassment and bullying. The ad is certainly not anti-sewing (a masculine role in 17th century Scotland), anti-piety (a masculine trait of medieval Europe), anti-wisdom, anti-courage, anti-integrity. To claim that the use of the term toxic masculinity = anti-male is a blatant strawman of the term.

There is nothing racial about the commercial, aside from the fact that there is a fair representation of men of colour. You assessment of feminism is in itself. No feminists (including myself) endorse castration. Addressing the too often trivialized issue of sexual harassment does not equate "castrating men". Feminists argue in favour of gender plurality, not gender erasure. In other words, masculinity is a varied and multifaceted phenomenon, not static and superficially narrow. I think you will benefit greatly from reading up on feminist theory by the likes of Judith Butler and bell hooks, rather than kneejerk against strawmanned caricatures of feminism. I dare you to find the word 'castration' in their body of work.

Research in diverse cultures demonstrates that fathers‚Äô warmth contributes greatly to children‚Äôs long-term favorable development. In studies of many societies and ethnic groups around the world, researchers coded paternal expressions of love and nurturance‚Äîevident in such behaviors as cuddling, hugging, comforting, playing, verbally expressing love, and praising the child‚Äôs behavior. Fathers‚Äô sustained affectionate involvement predicted later cognitive, emotional, and social competence as strongly as did mothers‚Äô warmth‚Äîand occasionally more strongly (Rohner & Veneziano, 2001; Veneziano, 2003). And in Western cultures, paternal warmth and secure attachment is associated with children‚Äôs mature social behavior and protects them against a wide range of difficulties, including childhood emotional and behavior problems and adolescent substance abuse and delinquency (Grant et al., 2000; Michiels et al., 2010; Nelson & Coyne, 2009; Tacon & Caldera, 2001).
Fathers who devote little time to physical caregiving express warmth through play. In a German study, fathers‚Äô play sensitivity‚Äîaccepting toddlers‚Äô play initiatives, adapting play behaviors to toddlers‚Äô capacities, and responding appropriately to toddlers‚Äô expressions of emotion‚Äîpredicted children‚Äôs secure internal working models of attachment during middle childhood and adolescence (Grossmann et al., 2002). Through play, fathers seemed to transfer to young children a sense of confidence about parental support, which may strengthen their capacity to master many later challenges.
What factors promote paternal warmth? Cross-cultural research reveals a consistent association between the amount of time fathers spend near infants and toddlers and their expressions of caring and affection (Rohner & Veneziano, 2001). Consider the Aka hunters and gatherers of Central Africa, where fathers spend more time in physical proximity to their babies than in any other known society. Observations reveal that Aka fathers are within arm‚Äôs reach of infants more than half the day. They pick up, cuddle, and play with their babies at least five times as often as fathers in other hunting-and-gathering societies. Why are Aka fathers so involved? The bond between Aka husband and wife is unusually cooperative and intimate. Throughout the day, couples share hunting, food preparation, and social and leisure activities. The more Aka parents are together, the greater the father‚Äôs loving interaction with his baby (Hewlett, 1992).
In Western cultures as well, fathers in gratifying marriages feel more confident about their parenting skills and spend more time with and interact more effectively with their infants. In contrast, marital dissatisfaction is associated with insensitive paternal care (Grych & Clark, 1999; Lundy, 2002; Sevigny & Loutzenhiser, 2010). Clearly, mothers‚Äô and fathers‚Äô warm interactions with each other and with their babies are closely linked. But paternal warmth promotes long-term favorable development, beyond the influence of maternal warmth (Rohner & Veneziano, 2001). Evidence for the power of fathers‚Äô affection, reported in virtually every culture and ethnic group studied, is reason to encourage more men to engage in nurturing care of young children.

@formerflash I think it's worth considering whether masculinity is even worth holding on to then. For the record I don't have a problem with men being feminine, I'm a skinny af dude who has a high pitched voice and cries at movies, I'm not exactly the masculine ideal lol. @T R I suppose the part that I'm struggling to come to gripes with within all of that is that I would absolutely refuse to call things like sexual assault a 'masculine behaviour'.

Nor would I agree with the point that violence is an acceptable part of the male psyche. We have a tolerance for it, but I'd reason that we have a tolerance for any violence as it's part of the 'human' psyche.

That being said a tolerance is far from acceptance. We tolerate that people can get angry and hurt people, but we don't accept these actions. If you hurt someone out of anger, you'd better have a damn good excuse for doing it, man or woman.

Statistics show that crimes of violence and violence in general is more likely to occur from men for a variety of reasons, (being physically stronger on average as an example), but I feel like the variance is too high to restrict such behaviours to men.

I've had many experiences in my life to base my claims around, the most prominent of those being that I, as a guy am very passive, lack a competitive nature almost entirely, and at times can be admittedly fairly emotional, grew up around women who are some of the hardest people I know to date.

I suppose to also clarify, I don't see a problem with the 'premise' of the theory, just the verbiage. I think that violence isn't practical in 99% of problems in todays world, but I think we shouldn't restrict the wording to men. Not only because it seems a bit dismissing to the fact that violence are occurred by men and women, but imagine how offensive it would sound to say that an aggressive women is being "toxically masculine".

I have not run into a situation where "boys will be boys" would be used to justify malicious behavior. In the minds of radical feminists of course that is the only use for it and there's a widespread acceptance for rape and torture of girls because of it.

Let's examine this further though. Procter & Gamble had a campaign with the "like a girl" phrase. To do something like a girl has meant that you are doing something clumsily. You might've seen a girl throw a ball for example and notice that they're on average not as skilled at it as boys. What did Procter & Gamble do? They certainly didn't use the phrase to shame girls and demand them to be better. Neither did they want that phrase to be banned. They instead wanted to change it to mean something positive. To do something "like a girl" would have to mean that it's done well. That's what they campaigned for.

Why does "boys will be boys" not get the same treatment? Why not embrace it and make it mean something positive? They settle with demonizing boys and that phrase is perfect for it. If boys can't be boys, what does that make boys? Bad.

The problem is when they establish the moral dichotomy between feminine and masculine behavior. For example they discourage aggression and encourage nurturing of children. The real moral dichotomy is not between feminine and masculine traits, those are complementary. The moral dichotomy is between the virtuous masculinity and the vicious masculinity. For example, in the realm of aggression you have to encourage the virtuous aggression and discourage the vicious one. You encourage men who fight to protect and you discourage those who fight to hurt. That is not incompatible with also adopting feminine traits which can be useful to men in some context. The framing of the dichotomy between the feminine and the masculine, especially when the focus is on negative aspect of masculine traits and the positive of the feminine, is what causes the polarized response. Also to be fair the Gillette ad did it right at some points, probably even more right than wrong, but it was mixed and it also was open to interpretation, because they were just quick scenes without much context or detail.

Honestly, I mostly take it as marketing, just like Nike supporting the controversial Colin football player.

Still, I think there is a sad reality of truth to what they‚Äôve said, and while I don‚Äôt think that we are all guilty of the level of assault and violence against women shown, I think we could all use multiple reminders that these things happen, and we can use our masculinity to make a difference.

First of all, I'm a huge fan of your show Joe! Been watching regularly for about a year now and I absolutely love it!

But I'm honestly¬†confused about why the commercial is so offensive? I am a 22-year-old Male and seem the be in the minority here when I think that the commercial really is not that offensive. 

I am aware that YouTube as apparently been pulling dislike from the video and if that's true then that's definitely not OK! I am aware that this is probably an attempt to rebrand by Gillette simply to exploit what they presumed was 'popular' to simply make money. I am aware that some 'feminists' can use words like 'toxic masculinity' way out of context, stereotype¬†and blame an entire gender for problems that are not fair to men and seek not to gain equality but to actually harm and oppress men. I also understand how many groups freak out when they have stereotypes associated with them. And I also understand that it is a double standard¬†(if the video were showing women in the same light people would freak out!)¬†

That being said I think we can do better and not freak out at every little thing and set an example on how to take criticism. It appears that the commercial really only highlights a couple things, (Violent Bullying, objectifying women in the Media and Music, degrading women in the workplace, rationalizing negative behavior through dogmatism "boys will be boys," and that Men should stand up when other men act in negative ways). These things are characteristics I think that are fair to associate with Men. And the commercial then shows that Men don't have to stick up with these things and can be better. The ad seems to indicate men that they can improve from these negative characteristics. Which I personally don't think is offensive.   

Love to hear other peoples thoughts and views! And I am honestly open to changing my opinion given new info

So, I wanted to see what the controversy was about. What is all the fuss about for people to boycott Gillette? Are people actually feeling so sensitive that they‚Äôre getting offended by this ad? All I see is that, the bottomline message is to encourage men to lead by example to hold each other accountable and courageously speak up and step in, when you witness behaviors that show signs of bullying, creepy objectification of women‚Äôs body, glorification of sexual harassment / violence, trivializing assault, defining ‚Äúmanhood‚Äù as aggressive behavior, or blaming the victim. There are plenty of masculine traits we all admire, such as absolute certainty, being trustworthy, decisive, confident, responsible, protective, logical, hardworking, empowering, and plenty of other noble masculine traits without being an asshole that belittles others and demeans women to make themselves look powerful. Do some men honestly feel attacked about this ad? Maybe the ones feeling attacked actually have something to feel guilty about?

@Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus I think I see where you're coming from, but please correct me if I am wrong. I dislike being labelled, to be generalized in a group. The ad makes you feel being lumped together, with all men oversimplified to being put in a box. However, from my perspective, I don't see the ad is trying to portray that. 

I guess the ad, just like any books such as the Bible or any piece of artwork, is open meant to invoke emotion, and the meaning is interpreted by the viewer. We shaped the world largely due to our own personal experiences, and we take away the message based on how we interpret the ad. 

The reason why this ad is perhaps well-received in certain aspect (even though I think the overall execution could have been done better), is that women feel empathized or reassured that a someone with power or status (such as a celebrity or company) is speaking up and taking a stand, to make a voice known in a way that perhaps is more difficult for men comprehend because they've never stepped into the shoes of a woman. If you ask a women in your life how likely it is to walk across a crowded bar/club without getting groped, how often it is to walk down a street without worrying being stalked or followed, or how frequent it for women to received unwelcome sexually explicit comment or touches, or how many women in our lives that have been harassed or assaulted... It may not be a daily worry of yours because it never happens to you, but ask any women in your life, "How often it is do you worry about your safety?" Chances are, it's pretty often. It could be as simple as walking back the the parking garage from your office. Just few weeks ago when in Chicago when I was walking to an item delivered next to an Amazon mail box, I was scared because a guy followed me for 3 blocks, and he lingered by pestering me with sexually suggestive questions and inappropriate remarks that made me feel uncomfortable when I was at the Amazon locker. After retrieving the items, he followed me for another block away from the gas station, and I felt so relieved when I got back to my Airbnb. 

The feeling of our safety being jeopardized can happen quite often for a woman, and I think the objective of the ad, in my opinion, is to challenge boys to become men, to have the courage to act as role models for other men, to step it up and help other if you see inappropriate behaviors of violence, harassment, or misogyny. For example, one of my friend old me when he was in college, his guy friend would have such "locker room talks" in a networking social event. One guy would point out, "Hey do you see those group of girls over girl wearing short skirts? They're just asking for it. I'm just gonna go over there and get them drunk and give it them." The other guys laughed. My friend didn't say anything, and stayed quiet to himself even though it bothered him. He told me in that in that moment, he could see that they were capitalistic and opportunistic, and made the demeaning comment inflate his ego. However, if it were to happen again, he would have stepped in and said, "Hey man, that's not cool. I don't appreciate that kind of language and that kind of assumption about those women. Cut it out." I feel that the intent of the ad is to encourage men to be accountable for other men, to challenge them to rise up on a higher level to be more decent human beings.

So Gillette's message is "hey guys, let's not be dicks anymore," and everyone is boycotting them now?  You guys realize that you just lost the ability to all anyone a "snowflake" or "triggered" without looking like a hypocritical douchebag, right?  

I really enjoy Joe Rogan's podcast.  He's a superb entertainer, he's incredibly smart and very well spoken.  This is right up there with the most disappointingly short-sighted take he's ever had.  "They made ever guy look like a misogynist asshole."  Watch the ad again, Joe.  That's patently false.  They show several situations that, until fairly recently, were either brushed under the rug or seen as completely acceptable.  They never said "ALL MAN ARE EVIL ASSHOLES AND MISOGYNISTS AND RAPISTS!!!"  Moreover, a good part of the ad focused on speaking up if you see another guy being a dick, or intervening if you see your kid being a dick.  WHAT THE FUCK IS SO ABHORRENTLY WRONG ABOUT ANY OF THIS?  God this clip bummed me out so much.   Ugh.  Theo Von, who is insanely funny and talented, asking "will men even have dicks in the future," and Rogan  incomprehensibly ignoring his ability to analyze the ad objectively and rationally in favor shitting all over it immediately.  I couldn't make it until the end, but I would be willing to bet the word "pussification" is used at some point in the clip.  

Yes, it's a little heavy handed.  Yes, it seems disingenuous simply because it's a company whose bottom line is making money that's putting out the message.  But are we really, REALLY shitting on a company that goes off the beaten path with an ad campaign that's aimed at bringing awareness to a movement that will result in fewer assaults, fewer instances of bullying and fewer rapes? ¬†

If you need to act like an abusive asshole to feel like a "real man," newsflash, you're not a "real man."  You're a monumentally insecure mental midget who lacks the intelligence and maturity to process your feelings like a goddamn adult. ¬†

But go ahead with your "boycotts."  I'm sure you all were wheelbarrowing stacks of cash, gold coins and rubies from your Scrooge McDuck vaults and spending every last farthing on Gillette razors.  And now without your mighty, oh-so-manly support, Gillette will be faced with the decision of groveling at your Air Max 90's for forgiveness or filing for bankruptcy and fading away into obscurity. ¬†

I have spent far too much time thinking about this today. It has been a day of long high speed train rides to and through France, so I have had the time. After some evaluation and research i think if they had really wanted to reach men and empower men to ‚Äúbe better‚Äù or ‚Äúthe vest they can be or whatever, they would have started with acknowledging all they do and simply shown examples of men setting an example, also in regards to standing up to each other when they treat women poorly.

The more I have been thinking about this the more I wonder if the result they got wasn‚Äôt exactly what they expected and part of a strategy. I started googling and found some thought pieces to support this.

Men are wearing more beards. Disposable razors are a shrinking market. Sales ro men have gone down about 5% a year for the last 5 or so years. Women shave a lot but often don‚Äôt splurge that bit extra for a gilette razor (legs and armpits versus face, whatevs...). But if they make women feel supported maybe women will start paying the dollar or two extra for Gillette. If women do that, they don‚Äôt need the shrinking male market as much.

I was surpised by the male backlash, maybe because I don‚Äôt live in the US and the Dutch would be unswayed by this, but I am guessing it is actually predictable. Gillette got the controversy and attention they wanted. This was a strategic play on their part and a smart one.

That said, people react to the intention with which you do something. They feel your actual purpose. In that sense, the backlash is well deserved and men are reacting the only way they could . They are being used as pawns to win the feminist market. The commercial pretends to be speaking to them but it isn‚Äôt and that is strategic. P&G is not stupid and their PR team knows what it is doing. They are playing us. And I guess we could say I got played too. 

Of course, men want to be better men and protect those they love and be sensitive to others‚Äô needs. And suggesting that they don‚Äôt (both try to do this and do it) is insulting. So, yeah, maybe the reaction we are seeing isn‚Äôt ridiculous as I initially saw it. Maybe I was just naive.

Well a lot of people had some choice words for me. That's ok, I wish you realized I'm on your side. Of course there is toxic femininity and ESPECIALLY toxic feminism. But my point isn't really about toxic masculinity...my point was that I think a lot of people misunderstood the point of the ad...it wasn't saying at all that men are bad, but applauding men and saying there are good, strong, powerful men sticking up for people weaker than them.

One person made the point that the commercial mentioned "some men" implying a minority. That's actually a really good point. They should have said "many men" or "a lot of men" instead. However, read some of the comments made towards me and maybe add up how many use derogatory words. Regardless, I still like to believe the majority of men are the good guys shown in the ad.

Some people mentioned "what if tampax made one about toxic female things!" and I have to say....they did. in 2014. It was Always, another tampon brand.

 They showed teenage women being told to do actions "like a girl" and the girls acted lazy, lame, weak, etc. It made girls look bad for a second. Then they showed little girls being told to do the same things, and they showed determination, effort, strength, etc. 

The point of that commercial was to say "do better, women. Because you are better. See? You're amazing and powerful and can make awesome changes!" ...Which was the EXACT same messages, in the same order, geared towards men in the gillette commercial. 

I saw the commercial and my first thought was "I love men!" I think a lot of people are really missing the point/main concept of the ad. I didn't like the commercial because I was happy they said men were bad! "yeah men suck!" ...no, I liked it because it made me appreciate the awesome strong men who have stood up for me or protected me in my own life in various ways.

(Also, they showed white men stopping bullying/harrasment too (barbecue, boys chasing scene) and black men doing the wrong thing too (black dad at barbecue, black guys about to fight). But maybe they should have made a more even split, that is a fair point.

Sometimes I think my dear fellow brothers can be idiots, and this is one of those occasions.¬† Please keep an open mind,
brothers, and I will walk you through what Gillette is doing.

First, and most importantly, to paraphrase the Godfather, this is a business decision, this is not personal.¬† This is only about making money.¬† As Milton Freeman once said, ‚ÄúThe social¬†responsibility of business¬†is to increase¬†profits‚Äù.

This ad was not and never was for men, it was for women, who overwhelmingly love this commercial.¬† Please stop thinking that we,
as men, are the center of the universe.

The ad was produced by an extraordinarily talented feminist film director, Kim Gehrig, for women, repeat for women. And Gehrig has brought almost all women together with
this commercial.¬† Did you really think Gillette would choose a feminist to sell to men? ¬†That is idiot thinking.

This was a well thought out strategy by Gillette management, just like the Kaepernick commercial was well thought out by Nike.

Why would Gillette want to appeal so much to women?  Women pay substantially more than men for equivalent Gillette products.¬† The higher prices for female products, often called the Gillette ‚Äúpink tax‚Äù, provides a much higher profit margin from women customers than men.

Gillette is willing to lose some male customers to win far more female customers with muchhigher female profit margins and thus earn higher profits.¬† This is called a gambit, and it can be an extraordinarily effective business strategy.

Please let me walk you through what Gillette is doing by explaining the Nike success.¬† Remember the uproar and planned boycotts when
Nike initially announced it was using Kaepernick in its commercials?¬† And yet the Kaepernick commercials were enormously profitable for Nike.

Nike knew it would lose and win customers using Kaepernick.¬† 

What Nike correctly projected was that the customers they would lose were cost-sensitive and low profit-margin customers (mainly white and older males) and the
customers they would gain would be higher profit-margin purchasers like African Americans and youth.¬† It was a gambit that worked big time.

The Gillette commercial will also work big time because women view this commercial as helping them, and those opposed to the commercial as the
Neanderthal thugs stereotyped in the commercial. ¬†Look at all the female comments about ‚Äúif you do not understand the commercial, you are the problem‚Äù.¬† Most women do not care about
negative male stereotyping and shaming in the commercial, and women are more than willing to pay the Gillette ‚Äúpink tax‚Äù to support Gillette in its efforts for its ‚Äúkindness‚Äù to women.

Yes, Gillette will probably lose some male customers, like me and some of you, who believe the negative male shaming is unhealthy for men and women and negative
stereotyping should not be done against any group in America.¬† Nevertheless, women do not see the problem with stereotyping males because they are not the ones being stereotyped so Gillette
will gain many more women customers from the ad than they will lose male customers. 

Remember, men, here is a simple rule for future advertising--fat shaming is bad, but male shaming is good.

Are there other advantages for Gillette beside profits from the ad?¬† Oh yes, like a magician uses misdirection, Gillette uses the ad to misdirect socially responsible people (1) away from
discussing Gillette‚Äôs use of child labor, (2) from the Gillette ‚Äúpink tax‚Äù, (3) from much better quality and lower-priced razors from competitors, (4) from Gillette‚Äôs
inappropriate sexist imaging of women (remember beautiful women in really tight blue jump suits with ‚ÄúGillette‚Äù written boldly on their butts?), and (5) from Gillette‚Äôs
parent company‚Äôs (P&G) testing products on animals.

With a simple ‚Äúabracadabra‚Äù, the Gillette magician has ‚Äúpoof‚Äù moved the discussion from Gillette toxicity to ‚Äúmasculine‚Äù toxicity.¬†

No one is talking now about Gillette toxicity.¬† In a way, I would like to stand up to Gillette‚Äôs toxicity, just like Gillette demonstrates in the commercial.¬† But no
one can effectively stand up to Gillette at this time because Gillette has effectively misdirected the entire world away from Gillette‚Äôs problems.

Gentlemen, do you still think that I am wrong?¬† Well, here is a big clue for you.  When corporations make big mistakes, the best practice is to always quickly
apologize for the mistake and to always quickly do whatever it takes to make amends.¬† Gillette is not apologizing because they know that they are going to make a fortune from this ad.

Instead, Gillette simply says that they are just trying to ‚Äúhelp‚Äù men become ‚Äúbetter‚Äù people, and who can be against that?¬† Watch how Gillette also now responds to negative comments by saying that ‚Äúmany‚Äù men are helping (when the ad emphasizes only ‚Äúsome‚Äù men are helping)‚Äîagain, a masterful use of quick misdirection).

Gentlemen, even if you hate the negative male stereotyping and male shaming in the commercial, as my Granny used to say, you still have to give the devil his due.¬† Like Nike, Gillette will make a fortune from this ad.

Ian Stevenson well, I think you are thinking a bit small. I don‚Äôt mean this in an offensive way, I just mean that I think the ad‚Äôs goal wasn‚Äôt as simple as ‚Äúlet‚Äôs get the toxic men to listen to us and be better‚Äù. I think they knew exactly what response they were going to get (all of this backlash) and I think that they were actually counting on it. I don‚Äôt think that for a second did they think men who actually do the bad things portrayed in the commercial would sit across their little screen and go ‚Äúyou are right, Gillette! Thanks for making me a better person! I‚Äôll change right now!‚Äù. That wasn‚Äôt their goal! That is stupid because everyone knows it would never happen and that‚Äôs small minded anyway. They want us all, as a society, to hold men who do that shit accountable and expect better of them as well as raise our children that way. They aren‚Äôt preaching to certain men to change, they‚Äôre preaching to us as a society to change in that respect (by not accepting that kind of behavior, mentality, etc). Furthermore, the backlash is key in this because that‚Äôs the only way nowadays to get people to talk about you. No one has ever talked about freaking razors as much as they are talking about it now. I think they hit two birds w one stone. And I couldn‚Äôt disagree more when u said a man should have directed it. That to me is the same as saying that only black people should talk about the usage of the word nigger or only whoever has been assaulted can talk about sexual assault and so forth. I think everyone regardless of gender, race, etc can talk about and have an opinion on anything they want. The directly affected may have a better inside look at it in some instances but everyone has the right to chime in on anything. So I‚Äôm ok with a woman directing this just as much as I‚Äôd be ok with a man making a commercial about how scary feminism can get in certain instances.

To close this I‚Äôll say that I only have two issues w the ad. The fact that they said ‚Äúsome‚Äù at a time in the ad when they talk about how men are breaking those stereotypes. I think they should have said ‚Äúmany‚Äù. Another possible problem is that it **MAY** be favoring non white men. I can understand why they said ‚Äúsome‚Äù instead of ‚Äúmany‚Äù and why they would (possibly) be favoring non white men but just because I get it, it doesn‚Äôt mean I‚Äôll agree with the choice, or like it. The ad is still great tho and I stand with it.

A real man IS sincere, kind, and honest.
A real man IS humble, confident, and secure‚ÄîNOT a show-off.
